title: From Pilots to Practice: Next Steps to Scale Circular Construction in the Nordics
notes: Complete transcription from Whisper. Three speakers identified: Jan Thomas Odegard (Natural State/Nordic Circular Construction), Helle Redder Momsen (Danish Authority), Anna Karlsdottir (Ludica Architects Iceland). Key themes: 9R Framework, Nordic maturity ranking, Building Less Movement, Material Harvesting, Hamkrid hempcrete project, Nine Policy Measures for existing buildings.

speakers.name: Helle Redder Momsen
speakers.organization: Nordic Network for Sustainable Construction / Danish Authority of Social Services and Housing

parts.title: Introduction and Challenges
parts.description: Session introduction and overview of circular construction challenges

segments.text: Welcome to partner session on circular construction. Three perspectives: Icelandic, government, and private sector. Nordic Circular Construction is one of four projects supported by Nordic Innovation.
16 companies involved in upscaling circular construction solutions. Nordic region aims to be most sustainable by 2030, but circularity scores remain among the lowest.

Seven-eight main challenges: linear domination (cheaper virgin materials), policy limitations, public procurement intentions without action, immature fragmented market, trust issues with circular products, low risk appetite, small reuse market with timing mismatches, slow construction times limiting experimentation.

parts.notes: Jan Thomas Odegard opens with overview of Nordic Circular Construction project and key challenges facing circular construction transition.

parts.title: Goals and the 9R Framework
parts.description: International targets and the 9R circularity framework

segments.text: Paris goals, 55% CO2 cut by 2030, Kunming-Montreal Agreement for 30% nature preservation. Global Resources Panel: 50%+ of CO2 emissions from resource use.
Amsterdam: 50% circular construction by 2030. Denmark: must reduce new construction by 80% by 2030. Norway: 72% material use reduction needed by 2030.

9R Framework: avoiding unnecessary buildings and transforming existing is best; recycling materials is least intensive. Different building parts have different durations requiring varied circularity approaches.

parts.notes: Overview of climate targets and the 9R framework for prioritizing circular construction strategies.

parts.title: Nordic Maturity Assessment
parts.description: Ranking of Nordic countries on circular construction maturity

segments.text: Nordic circular construction maturity ranking: Netherlands (pioneer benchmark) > Denmark/Finland (leading) > Sweden > Norway > Iceland > Greenland (starting from scratch).
Two axes for progress: regulatory maturity (harmonization) and market side (supply/demand stimulation). Moving together accelerates progress.

parts.notes: Assessment of where each Nordic country stands on circular construction maturity.

parts.title: Building Less Movement
parts.description: The sufficiency movement and building stop initiatives

segments.text: Building Stop Movement (Denmark) / Sufficiency Movement (Europe). Danish 'bevare eller forklare' (preserve or explain) becoming law-like. New Finnish building law has similar elements.

Helsinki converting abandoned COVID-era office space to housing. Norway/Denmark: taking 10% of large houses for small flats could create 130,000 units each - exactly Norway's 5-year housing target. Over 200,000 unused buildings in Norwegian districts.

parts.notes: Discussion of building sufficiency movements and potential for existing building stock utilization.

parts.title: Material Harvesting and Reuse
parts.description: Transition from demolition to material harvesting

segments.text: Moving from brute demolition to material harvesting. Norwegian broadcasting company site doing selective deconstruction with Danish architects.

EU target: 70% reuse/recycle. Norway far behind with disincentives: minimal landfill fees, demolition-encouraging taxes, large energy recovery sector. Denmark leads with selective deconstruction law, CO2/sqm limits, zero CO2 for reused materials.

Reuse hubs growing but mostly small, private, catering to individuals. Major gap: no B2B segment with volumes, quality, certification. Stark (Denmark) now selling circular products from companies like Bricks.

parts.notes: Overview of material harvesting practices and the gap in B2B circular construction markets.

parts.title: Circular Construction Product Catalog
parts.description: Overview of Nordic circular construction companies and products

segments.text: 15 companies in Nordic Circular Construction catalog: Bricks (reclaimed), milk carton boards, Danish Nester (reclaimed wood bike sheds), Entree Norway (reclaimed wood materials), Icelandic textile, Danish Arup (services), Carbonade (CO2-captured concrete), Nordic Circle (marine steel beams), Bilt (transformation), ReCircle (rehab), Make a BIM Finland (AI BIM models), FIRA Finland (interior/ventilation).

Market accelerator program: expand catalog to 15-100 best solutions, platform for suppliers, invite demand side. Key: information access on availability, prices, certification. Many property owners don't know these products exist.

parts.notes: Introduction of Nordic circular construction product catalog and plans for market acceleration.

parts.title: Iceland's Built Heritage

segments.text: Anna Karlsdottir, co-founder of Ludica Architects. Practice dedicated to research and experimentation, exploring alternatives to extractive construction paradigm.
Construction history from 9th century settlement: turf, stone, timber dwellings. Kjeldur - oldest existing turf farmhouse from 12th century. People lived in turf houses until 20th century.
Concrete dominance by 20th century - now 80% of Icelandic buildings are concrete. Shift from 900 years of biodegradable structures to permanent, resource-intensive systems.

parts.notes: Anna Karlsdottir presents Iceland's construction heritage from turf houses to concrete dominance.

parts.title: Iceland's Circular Construction Position
parts.description: Current state and challenges for Iceland

segments.text: Island nation with limited building materials beyond stone, turf, driftwood. Harsh climate, earthquakes, volcanic activity create unique testing ground.
Lagging in linear-to-circular transition due to small population, fragmented markets, significant information gaps. Many gaps now identified and being addressed.
2015-2020: 88% recycling ratio for building/demolition waste. 2030 target: 95% recycling, 5% disposal. However, most 'recycling' is mixed mineral waste backfilling - not high-value circular use.

parts.notes: Analysis of Iceland's position in circular construction transition.

parts.title: Qualitative Growth Philosophy

segments.text: Development as qualitative transformation, not quantitative growth. GDP ignores unpaid labour, community resilience, ecosystem services, cultural value.
Global capitalism treats air, water, soil as expendable commodities. Private profit at public cost. Belief in unlimited growth on finite planet is fundamentally flawed.
Need qualitative growth that regenerates rather than exploits. Most environmentally friendly building is the one that already exists. Circular construction and bio-based building intersect here.

parts.notes: Philosophical reflection on redefining growth and development in construction.

parts.title: Hamkrid Hempcrete Project

segments.text: After returning from London, struck by Iceland's concrete and import dependence. Industrial hemp seeds became legal to import - sparked bio-building project idea.
Project goals: use local/natural building materials, minimize ground intervention, design for disassembly and reuse, share knowledge openly.
First obstacle: regulation. No CE marking possible, so couldn't get standard building permit. Workaround: keep structure under 15m² and 2.5m height. Innovation operated within a loophole.
Iceland's first temporary hempcrete building. Used local structural timber, Icelandic larch cladding, rock wool insulation, red scoria pathways, seaweed for experiments.

parts.notes: Case study of the Hamkrid project - Iceland's first hempcrete building.

parts.title: Information Gap and Future Matters
parts.description: Research gaps and the Future Matters initiative

segments.text: Profound information gap discovered. No official statistics from 2010 on building material imports. Needed 'a guy who knew a guy' for local material data.
Future Matters initiative emerged: collaborative research with Trípuli architectar and Gísli Rafa Magnusson. Exploring architectural heritage, current practices, possible futures.
Future Matters aims to be: toolkit for change, knowledge repository, platform for experimental practice, critical policy review, stakeholder network.

parts.notes: Discussion of information gaps in Iceland and the Future Matters research initiative.

parts.title: Key Discoveries in Iceland

segments.text: Patterns identified: loss of research infrastructure, decline in local manufacturing, forgotten material techniques, globalized economic pressure, limited market scale, no research facility.
Also found: rich material heritage, experimental potential, regenerative possibilities, opportunity for local value creation.

Post-WWII innovation: pumice from Hekla for building blocks (houses still standing after 20 years unclad), red scoria blocks (70s-80s houses), rammed earth building stood 100 years until torn down this year.

Iceland at interesting crossroads: scale makes industrial competition difficult but provides agility, proximity, rapid systemic change potential. Circular construction is technical, cultural, and political challenge.

parts.notes: Summary of key findings from Icelandic research and future potential.

parts.title: Nordic Government Collaboration
parts.description: Introduction to Nordic government cooperation on construction

segments.text: Helle Redder Momsen from Danish Authority of Social Services and Housing. Part of Nordic Sustainable Construction Collaboration - colleagues from all Nordic countries working on green, digital, circular transition.
Nordic vision: most sustainable and integrated region by 2030. Built environment is key to achieving this.
Nordic ministers of housing and construction 2023 declaration: work towards low carbon solutions, integrate circular principles, recognized potential in preserving existing building stock.

parts.notes: Helle Redder Momsen introduces Nordic government collaboration on sustainable construction.

parts.title: Collaboration Structure
parts.description: Timeline and structure of Nordic construction collaboration

segments.text: Previous collaboration 2021-2024. New collaboration June 2025 to end of 2027 with existing building stock as key focus.
All Nordic construction authorities involved. Lead countries take responsibility for work packages; Finland, Faroe Islands, Greenland, Norway contribute input.

Beyond Zero collaboration established foundational knowledge. Key question: at what pace can we consume materials formed over billions of years? Most sustainable building is one kept in use and loved.

parts.notes: Details on Nordic construction collaboration timeline and structure.

parts.title: Building Hierarchy
parts.description: Finnish architecture policy building hierarchy framework

segments.text: Triangle from Finnish architecture policy 2022 (Matti Kutten). Priority order: 1) Use what's already there, 2) Prolong lifetime with maintenance, 3) Renovate/transform, 4) Extend existing, 5) Build new (with reused products if needed).
Existing building stock negative footprint: greenhouse emissions, virgin resource depletion, waste, biodiversity loss, eutrophication, chemicals, social imbalance.
Focus on existing buildings can solve: housing shortage, health crisis, sustainability goals, affordability.

parts.notes: Presentation of the building hierarchy framework prioritizing existing buildings.

parts.title: Nine Policy Measures
parts.description: Policy measures for existing building stock

segments.text: Nine policy measures mapped: 1) Lifetime extension, 2) Demolition prevention/criteria, 3) Remove barriers for renovation, 4) Multi-use and efficient square meter utilization, 5) Incentives and tax instruments, 6) Design optimization, 7) Design for disassembly, 8) Procurement muscle, 9) Research, demonstration, piloting.

Nordic Climate Forum for Construction (Denmark hosted): Priorities ranked - 1) Lifetime extension, 2) Demolition prevention, 3) Remove regulatory barriers, 4) Incentives/tax, 5) Research/demonstration/piloting.

parts.notes: Overview of nine policy measures and priority ranking from Nordic Climate Forum.

parts.title: Implementation Details
parts.description: Specific implementation approaches for policy measures

segments.text: Methods: relaxation of change-of-use regulations, economic incentives for maintenance, minimize demolition, long-term planning with building history.
Focus on overcoming regulatory barriers, making renovation the easy choice over demolition, defining resource efficiency.
Multi-use potential exists but needs measurement methods to identify unused square meters.

parts.notes: Detailed implementation approaches for priority policy measures.

parts.title: Reused Products and Skills
parts.description: Assessment methods and education for reused materials

segments.text: Need to reduce risk/insecurity with reused materials. LCA calculations: most countries value reuse products at zero (to motivate market), some add transport emissions.
Working on Nordic assessment method for reused construction products. Mapping existing methods. Goal: contribute to EU construction product regulation.
Online education materials for teachers of carpenters and bricklayers on construction sustainability. Available in six Nordic languages plus English. Free to use.

parts.notes: Discussion of assessment methods for reused products and educational resources.

parts.title: Session Closing
parts.description: Closing observations and call to action

segments.text: Regulations still favor linear approaches. Big economic interests resist change - Norway's construction industry is largest industry. Need to get big companies seeing circularity as opportunity, not threat.
Political awareness of circularity improved in Norway over past year. Circularity is traditional - Norwegian houses historically designed for disassembly. Look back to find way forward.

Critical need: set clear goals. No politician has stated circular construction targets for climate/nature goals. Amsterdam has done it. Without clear goals, hard to set policies. Nordic platform can encourage countries but has no legal force.

parts.notes: Session closing with call for clear political goals on circular construction.

keyQuotes.speaker: Jan Thomas Odegard
keyQuotes.quote: The Nordics as a region wants to be the most sustainable and integrated region in the world by 2030. But circularity in general is very low. That's among some of the lowest.
keyQuotes.context: Opening remarks on Nordic sustainability paradox

keyQuotes.speaker: Jan Thomas Odegard
keyQuotes.quote: Denmark must reduce its new construction with 80% by 2030 to reach its goals.

keyQuotes.speaker: Jan Thomas Odegard
keyQuotes.quote: A traditional house in Norway is one that you can disassemble. And the Danes love it as their summer house even. You can pick it apart and then move it around.

keyQuotes.speaker: Anna Karlsdottir
keyQuotes.quote: For nearly 900 years we built structures that were biodegradable, required constant care and returned to the earth when they were no longer in use. In contrast, our modern material systems are permanent, resource-intensive and environmentally burdensome.

keyQuotes.speaker: Anna Karlsdottir
keyQuotes.quote: The real challenge lies in the implementation - how to shift from linear extraction to circular, regenerative systems in a meaningful and effective way.

keyQuotes.speaker: Anna Karlsdottir
keyQuotes.quote: Innovation literally operated within a loophole.

keyQuotes.speaker: Anna Karlsdottir
keyQuotes.quote: If concrete brought Iceland to modernity, what brings us into a regenerative future?

keyQuotes.speaker: Helle Redder Momsen
keyQuotes.quote: The most sustainable building is the one that is kept in use and loved.

keyQuotes.speaker: Helle Redder Momsen
keyQuotes.quote: At which pace can we consume materials which have taken billions of years to form?

keyQuotes.speaker: Jan Thomas Odegard
keyQuotes.quote: Until now, I haven't found one politician who can say, we're going to be this much circular in construction to achieve our climate and nature goals.

themes.description: Despite ambitious sustainability goals, Nordic construction circularity rates remain among the lowest globally
Current regulations favor linear approaches and hinder circular innovation, requiring reform
Need for B2B circular construction products market with proper volumes, certification, and accessibility
Preserving and optimizing existing buildings offers greatest sustainability potential
Historical Nordic construction was inherently circular; reconnecting with heritage can guide future
Lack of data on material flows, local resources, and assessment methods hampers progress
Need for clear, measurable circularity targets to drive policy and industry action
